title: MetaMask co-founder unpacks vision for reaching a 'much bigger audience'

rawLines.text: Hello and welcome to the Cryptobe. My
name is Tim Copeland. I'm the head of
credit at the block. Joining me today,
we have the co-founder of MetaMask, Dan
Finley. Welcome to the show. How are you
doing? Uh, hey Tim. Uh, doing great.
Thanks for having me. Amazing. Before we
get started, just a quick note. If you
are hiring in crypto, you should check
out Campus. Out of all of your
candidates, it will help you pick out
the real crypto natives. Head to the
block.co/campus. Get a 3-month free
trial. Now today's episode is all about
crypto wallets and the Ethereum
ecosystem. U but I want to start with uh
Dan, you've been in the crypto industry
a long time. Looking back at sort of
your entire time in the industry, how do
you think the space has changed over the
years? Oh well, it's I mean it's changed
immeasurably. like it went from being a
thing that very very few people had
heard of, let alone had any grasp of
what uh what it did or how it worked or
like or let alone had ideas about what
it could do to now it's like um now
there's like a battleground of
narratives. There's like there's like so
many ideas and visions of what it could
do or what it could be and even just
mental models of what it's good for. Um
so so I think that we're the the
technology has matured so far and yet
you know I think people are still really
really fighting just with much more
force and much larger populations about
um what exactly it's going to be good
for and how we're going to be using it.
Yeah, it does seem like there's an awful
lot of projects fighting for arguably
like a small number of sort of dedicated
users. Do you get that impression? Uh
yeah, I think I think it varies like
projects can choose to kind of fight for
the existing crypto group and and I
think that there's a you know I I don't
want to be too sour on it, you know, but
like like preying on people who have
money already is one business strategy
and it's enjoyed by you know scammers
among others. Um, I I have kind of
always approached this with a mindset of
like we're trying to build something
that's for a much bigger audience. And
so the the current users like I think I
think can sometimes feel a little
neglected while we build out what we
identify as longer term infrastructure
stuff that's not just necessary to make
apps marginally uh better but um the
changes that are needed to kind of
enable long-term transformation that
that this technology is really capable
of. Um so you can you can take it either
way and I think there are really teams
that do both. you know, you can fight
for existing mind share or you can try
to grow the pie. And I think there's a
lot of pie to grow. I think we're still,
despite how big in in kind of financial
prominence crypto is, I think there's a
lot of pie to grow, but there's a lot of
legitimacy to gain. You know, I think
from people that are not in crypto, a
kind of sour perception of it, you know,
there's there's not there's a lot of a
lot of taking advantage of people. Um,
not as many constructive things as there
could be. And what's your what's your
strategy? I mean, I assume you have
quite a lot. I mean, you have a large
market share already, so I assume you're
more focused on new users as opposed to
existing ones. I was curious on your
strategy in that regard. Yeah. Yeah.
There there is like a saying that that I
I sometimes repeat, which is like um
when when you're an underdog, you you
try to take, you know, a bigger slice of
the pie. And when you're the the bigger
uh dog, then you try to grow the pie. I
really think everybody could grow the
pie, but but yeah, we're we're
definitely in a position where we have
enough web 3 market share that it would
be very unproductive for us to be trying
to take it from other uh crypto wallets
or something. So, we have to be talking
about and thinking about um really
transformative uses and not just like
slightly more engaging uses for the
existing crypto users, but like like
uses that actually would justify usage
for people who are not interested in
crypto today. Um and and yeah, that that
involves everything from like of course
people like pointing out the friction.
So that means you need to eliminate like
the the barriers of either it's you know
key backup or getting crypto to pay for
gas and things like that and all the
complexity and the unreadability of
transactions um all the way up to like
the usefulness, the actual utility like
what's it good for? Is it just good for
speculating on meaningless things? Or is
this actually a better way to manage
something of value, something of real
value? Is this a way to run a company?
Is this a way to start a neighborhood
organization? Is this a way to run your
group chat? You know, like um until
normal people are reaching for these
tools um not thinking crypto, but
thinking like this is this is a great
product. This is giving me opportunity I
didn't have before. um then we we have
not remotely realized the the
opportunity in front of us. Are there
any use cases uh that you find
particularly interesting that you think
will appeal to a a much more sort of
normie audience?
Um yeah. Yeah. I I think that there are
just uh there are countless
opportunities for use cases that will
appeal to normie audiences. I think I
think that for one thing
um making it easier to to monetize the
things that you do like even in small

monetizing creations um you know tapping

mechanism. Um and and also yeah like

really ripe opportunity although it's

there's a strong sense that um the way

who who knows how many years, maybe 10

having immutable, transparent

that individuals kind of starting
collectives uh cooperatives, small

Um I was I I tend to look at things that

I was looking at one that's helping

for pro profit. I mean I I obviously use

the the current kind of crypto uh heavy
uh applications. Um but
um a lot of those are it's kind of like
the crypto crowd having fun with itself

it it's um yeah, it's a a grant program

called the heart of spritly paper and um
I think it's it along with um some of
the work we've been doing at Agoric u

think has a really great uh opportunity
to be a foundation of a alternative web.
So, you know, blockchains being great

right access, things like that. You
know, a lot of the current like Twitter
clones, they they clone Twitter to such
an extreme case that they kind of

these these problems all kind of come

Um, Spritley um and and Endo are both

we we think it's really useful. We're
we're funding it largely because we

really great flexibility for our own

dynamic distributed flexible wallet. Um,
you know, you might be familiar that

Snaps. So, we've got a little sandbox in

operating system. Um, but the way that
these extensions work right now is just
via RPC calls, which is like pretty

already. Um, with one of these kind of
object capability systems, we'll be able
to create a very dynamic mesh of
permissions between all of the
extensions. uh and those extensions
could exist off the user's device. And
so that's when things I think are going
to start getting really interesting. I
think there's some serious Cambrian
explosion opportunity there. And it all
it all enables the faster acceleration
and experimentation of all this other
stuff, right? Um all the all the
problems we have with uh web 3 largely
relate to navigating a permissionless
ecosystem. How do you read it? How do

are credible? Who do you trust? What
what are the projects you want to fund?
Um, and so sourcing credible information
I I don't think will always look like a
public square thing. I think public
square ends up looking a lot like a
couple influencers gaining the public
ear directing them towards questionable
investments until they lose favor and
then bat on loop basically. Um, I think
preserving the social graph, which means
often privacy and selective disclosure,
um, is going to be a a very big unlock
that people just aren't really
experiencing yet, other than in kind of

Um, yeah. So, I mean, building software

Um but uh we're hoping that um some of

How many employees do you have now? I I
do not know off hand. I think it's it's
around 500. let's say in for all of

it's fair to say better user experiences

it's still not where I want it. I mean,

Okay, well now we can make that one

That's that's a big improvement too. And

that'll start to chomp at that 40% of of

is a
